questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical checkup. The patient is asymptomatic. Her past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies, for which she takes loratadine. She had an uncomplicated cholecystectomy 25 years ago. Last menstrual period was 12 years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient is started on denosumab. This medication inhibits osteoclast formation and activity by binding to which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan is suggestive of osteoporosis. Denosumab can be administered for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.  

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody that binds the RANK ligand (RANKL) and inhibits its binding to RANK receptors on the surface of osteoclasts and their precursors. These effects prevent the activation and maturation of osteoclasts, which ultimately limits bone breakdown.    

In addition to treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, denosumab can be administered to prevent skeletal-related events (e.g., bone pain, fractures) in patients with bone metastases.  

Common side effects include hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and infections. Rarely can the medication cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.  



Option Analysis

❌ Calcium-sensing receptors:
Incorrect: Cinacalcet lowers parathyroid hormone levels by activating the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands. It is effective in treating hypercalcemia in parathyroid cancer and secondary hyperparathyroidism in chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Hydroxyapatite crystal:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate) reduce both the resorption and formation by binding to hydroxyapatite, which is the mineralized form of calcium found in bones. When osteoclasts break down bones, they also take in the bisphosphonates. The medication interferes with osteoclast function and promotes osteoclast apoptosis, thereby suppressing bone turnover. Denosumab is not a bisphosphonate and works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ RANK ligand:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcitonin receptors:
Incorrect: Calcitonin binds to calcitonin receptors and inhibits bone resorption. In contrast, denosumab’s mechanism of action does not involve calcitonin receptors.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone receptors:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog that acts through PTH receptors. When administered in a pulsatile fashion, the medication can promote osteoblastic activity and bone formation. In contrast, denosumab does not bind PTH receptors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a wellness checkup. The patient recently had a dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan that placed her at two standard deviations below the mean for bone density and is following up today to discuss the results. Past medical history is notable for asthma, anxiety, irritable bowel syndrome, and radial fracture that occurred 5-months ago following a ground-level fall. Current medications include clonazepam and albuterol. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is started on raloxifene in addition to weight-bearing exercise and vitamins. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is started on raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), to treat postmenopausal osteoporosis.    

Raloxifene has a partial agonist effect on estrogen receptors in the bones. Therefore it is useful in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. In addition, it is an estrogen receptor antagonist in the endometrium and breast tissue. As a result, raloxifene can also be used to prevent breast cancer.      

Common side effects include hot flashes and an increased risk of venous thrombosis.   

 

Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen, another selective estrogen receptor modulator, has an agonist effect on the endometrial receptors, promoting endometrial hyperplasia and increasing the risk of endometrial cancer. In contrast, raloxifene is an agonist at estrogen receptors in the bone but an antagonist at receptors in the endometrium.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: Selective estrogen receptor modulators such as raloxifene are effective in treating hormone-responsive breast cancer, where it acts as an antagonist to prevent receptor activation by endogenous estrogens. It does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer.  
❌ Osteonecrosis of jaw:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates are associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with this complication.   
✅ Deep vein thrombosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: The use of teriparatide, a parathyroid hormone analog, in patients with Paget disease of the bone can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with osteosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of persistent, dull bone pain. The patient has a history of metastatic breast cancer and is currently undergoing systemic chemotherapy. The pain is relieved occasionally by acetaminophen and oxycodone. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a right-sided mastectomy scar and a palpable right supraclavicular lymph node. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on intravenous zoledronic acid. Is this patient at increased risk of developing one of the following symptoms?  

 Laboratory Value  Result
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  420 U/L 
 Creatinine  1 mg/dL 
 Calcium  12 mg/dL 
 Glucose  138 mg/dL

choices.text: Swelling around the eyes and lips

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with hypercalcemia in the setting of metastatic breast cancer to the bone. She is started on bisphosphonate therapy.   

Oral bisphosphonates are most commonly associated with upper gastrointestinal side effects, such as esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, and gastric irritation. Individuals are advised to take oral bisphosphonates with plenty of water and stay upright for at least 30 minutes.  

On the other hand, intravenous bisphosphonates do not cause gastrointestinal disturbances but can lead to rare and more severe side effects, such as jaw osteonecrosis. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting:
Incorrect: Oral bisphosphonates are associated with upper gastrointestinal side effects, such as esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, and gastric irritation. Intravenous bisphosphonates do not typically cause gastrointestinal disturbances.
✅ Jaw pain and swelling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overgrowth of gum tissue  :
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a side effect of phenytoin and cyclosporine. It is not an adverse effect of bisphosphonates.  
❌ Exertional chest pain and tightness:
Incorrect: Triptans, the first-line treatment for migraines, can cause coronary vasospasm and chest pain exertions. In contrast, bisphosphonates do not cause vasoconstriction.  
❌ Swelling around the eyes and lips:
Incorrect: Angioedema can result from increased bradykinin production in patients receiving angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g. lisinopril). Bisphosphonates do not increase bradykinin levels and would not cause these side effects.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical examination. The patient has left hip pain, attributed to Paget disease of the bone diagnosed three years ago. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient is allergic to penicillin. Her last menstrual period was ten years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient inquires about a new PTH-analogue, teriparatide. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication in this patient?

choices.text: Personal history of Paget disease of the bone

questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.7, which is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Teriparatide is an effective treatment option for postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is, however, contraindicated in this patient given her history of Paget disease of the bone.  

Teriparatide is a recombinant analog of the parathyroid hormone given subcutaneously once per day. When given in a pulsatile fashion, it works by stimulating osteoblasts and reducing their apoptosis, resulting in a net increase in bone formation.    

Common side effects include transient hypercalcemia and an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. The medication should be avoided when the patient has other diseases that also increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma, such as those with Paget disease of bone.  




Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Family history of breast cancer is not a contraindication to teriparatide.  
✅ Personal history of Paget disease of the bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent pneumococcal vaccine administration:
Incorrect: Interaction between a vaccine and a drug has been reported only with the influenza vaccine and four drugs, which are aminopyrine, phenytoin sodium, theophylline, and warfarin sodium. The pneumococcal vaccine does not interact with teriparatide.  
❌ Penicillin allergy:
Incorrect: There is no cross-reactivity between penicillin and teriparatide.  
❌ Postmenopausal state:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a suitable medication for treating postmenopausal osteoporosis. The medication can be safely administered to women in a postmenopausal state.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with his parents due to knee pain. During the past few months, the patient noticed a non-painful bump on the right knee that has progressively grown in size. Last week, he fell on the same location and endorses pain at the site. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a bony bump is noted on the right knee with overlying lacerated skin and crusted blood. The patient is able to bear weight without pain. The range of motion is full, strength is 5/5, and sensation is intact. A CT of the knee is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

The patient is prepared for surgery. Which of the following is most likely to be found on pathohistological examination of this patient’s lesion?

choices.text: Haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue
Sheets of primitive small round cells

questions.solution:
This patient has an osteochondroma (exostosis), a benign overgrowth of cartilage. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long tubular bones, especially near the knee. Osteochondromas can be sessile or pedunculated, ranging from 1 to 20 cm in size. The cap consists of benign hyaline cartilage which appears as a disorganized growth plate that eventually undergoes endochondral ossification, with new bone-forming at the inner part. It occurs in individuals at ages 10-30 and is more common in men. Clinically, it may cause pain if it impinges the surrounding tissue or nerve. It can occur as a single lesion or multiple as part of the multiple hereditary exostoses syndrome. Rarely, osteochondromas progress to chondrosarcoma. Most osteochondromas can be observed but symptomatic ones are cured via an excision.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with osteoid osteoma, a benign bone producing tumor. In adolescents, osteoid osteomas often arises in the cortex of the femur or tibia. On histology, it is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. Osteoid osteoma appears on imaging as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim.  
❌ Malignant cells producing woven bone:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with osteosarcoma, the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic).   
✅ Chondrocytes and hyaline cartilage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sheets of osteoclasts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with giant cell tumor of bone (osteoclastoma), a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor seen in young adults. It typically arises in the epiphyses of long bones and may produce pain that mimics arthritis. X-ray typically shows an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” appearance. Grossly, they appear as red-brown masses with areas of cystic degeneration. Microscopically, it consists of sheets of osteoclast-type giant cells.  
❌ Sheets of primitive small round cells :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Ewing sarcoma, a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. It commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. The tumor usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. On histology, small sheets of malignant cells are seen.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic with his parents due to progressive right leg pain. He first noticed it during basketball training, but after some time, it even occurred at rest. The pain is dull, 3/10, and often wakes him at night. Medical history is significant for an eye problem as a baby. The patient’s parents say that he was treated for strabismus and “white eye” as a baby, but they do not recall the details. The patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100 °F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, focal tenderness is noted over the right tibia. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. An x-ray of the right leg is shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Constitutive activation of tyrosine kinase receptor
Abnormal G1–S checkpoint cell cycle regulation
Amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor

questions.solution:
This child is presenting with low-grade fever, progressive bone pain, and a classic Codman’s triangle appearance on x-ray, favoring the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. Given the medical history of “white eye,” the most likely mutated gene is the retinoblastoma (RB) gene.  

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to elevation of the periosteum and the characteristic imaging finding known as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic). Risk factors for developing osteosarcoma include RB gene mutation, TP53 mutations (Li-Fraumeni syndrome), prior irradiation or chemotherapy, Paget disease, fibrous dysplasia, and other benign bone lesions.  

The RB gene, also known as the governor of the cell cycle, is a tumor suppressor gene and a key negative regulator of the cell cycle. The product of the RB gene is the RB protein, which regulates the G1/S checkpoint of the cell cycle before DNA replication commences. When RB protein is hypophosphorylated, it binds the E2F transcription factor to inhibit gene transcription. When RB is phosphorylated it releases E2F, which binds DNA and activates transcription of S-phase genes. Mutations in the RB gene result in abnormal progression through the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and division. RB gene germline (inherited) or somatic (acquired) mutations are associated with retinoblastoma eye cancer, osteosarcoma bone cancer, and other soft tissue tumors.    

Option Analysis

❌ Constitutive activation of tyrosine kinase receptor:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of chronic myelogenous leukemia. The condition arises when a part of the ABL gene is translocated from its normal location on chromosome 9 to chromosome 22. This fusion gene encodes the BCR-ABL hybrid protein, a constitutively active tyrosine kinase protein that leads to downstream signals and cell growth. Tyrosine kinase is not involved in osteosarcoma.   
✅ Abnormal G1–S checkpoint cell cycle regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Impaired apoptosis:
Incorrect: TP53, also known as the guardian of the genome, is a tumor suppressor gene and is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer. The product of this gene, the p53 protein, is a transcription factor that prevents neoplastic transformation via temporary cell cycle arrest (quiescence), permanent cell cycle arrest (senescence), or apoptosis. TP53 mutation is associated with certain cases of osteosarcoma as part of Li-Fraumeni-syndrome. However, this child’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor:
Incorrect: HER2 is a type of epidermal growth factor receptor (tyrosine kinase) that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by activating the RAS- and PI3K-AKT signaling pathways. Mutation in the HER2 gene causes overexpression of this receptor, which leads to highly proliferative tumors and poor prognosis. The HER2 gene mutation is associated with breast cancer, but HER2-positive breast cancer is not inherited and is considered a somatic genetic mutation. This patient’s history and type of cancer favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Impaired degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor:
Incorrect: A mutation in the VHL gene would result in impaied degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a and result in von Hippel-Lindau disease. The condition is characterized by the development of multiple tumors, including central nervous system hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic tumors. However, it would be atypical for von Hippel-Lindau disease to manifest with a bone tumor.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to limping and pain in the right leg. The patient is a very active child who likes to run and play, but during the past few weeks, he was reluctant to go out and play. The patient’s parent also noticed he was limping. He often complains of night pain, which his parents attributed to growing pain. They gave him some acetaminophen, which provided relief. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lower part of the right fibula. The range of motion is full, and the rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. An x-ray is obtained and reveals a 1.5 cm lucent nidus surrounded by a rim of osteosclerotic reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pain that is relieved by medication and a characteristic nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim, favoring the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma (OO).   

Both OO and osteoblastoma (OB) are types of benign bone producing tumors that share similar histologic features but differ clinically and exhibit different radiologic appearance. On histology, they are well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. Osteoid osteomas also elicit reactive sclerosis which surrounds the lesion. Malignant transformation is rare.  



Option Analysis

✅ Osteoid osteoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoblastoma :
Incorrect: Both osteoid osteoma and osteoblastoma are types of benign bone producing tumors that share similar histologic features but differ clinically and exhibit different radiologic appearance. Osteoblastoma typically occurs at the vertebrae, is larger than 2 cm, and is unresponsive to aspirin or other NSAIDs. Also, it does not cause a marked osteosclerotic reaction.  
❌ Ewing sarcoma:
Incorrect: Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. The majority of Ewing sarcomas contain a balanced t(11;22) translocation. The tumor commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. It usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with a significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. This patient’s age and tumor location favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Osteochondroma:
Incorrect: Osteochondroma (exostosis) is a benign overgrowth of cartilage which can be sessile or pedunculated. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long tubular bones and often around the knee. It occurs in individuals at ages 10-30 and is more common in men. Osteochondroma may cause pain if it impinges the surrounding tissue or nerve. It can occur as a single lesion or multiple as part of the multiple hereditary exostoses syndrome. This patient’s imaging findings suggest another diagnosis.  
❌ Osteosarcoma :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic). This patient’s presentation and imaging findings suggest another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive fatigue and back pain over the past few months. Initially, the patient attributed the pain to strenuous work in the garden but decided to seek care when he noticed no improvement. The patient also noted a 10 lb (4.5 kg) weight loss without changes in his diet. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years and diabetes mellitus type 2. Laboratory values are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  11.2 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin   90 fl 
 Creatinine   2.3 mg/dL 
 Total protein  9.5 
 Albumin  3.2 g/dL 
 Sodium   132 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium  12 mg/dl  

Radiograph of the spine reveals multiple areas of hyperlucency at the lumbar and thoracic regions. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive fatigue, back pain, hypercalcemia, normocytic anemia, renal failure, and lytic bone lesions, all favoring the diagnosis of multiple myeloma (MM).   

MM is a neoplastic proliferation of plasma cells that produce monoclonal immunoglobulin (M protein). The most common M protein produced by myeloma cells is IgG, followed by IgA, and occasionally κ or λ light chains (light chains are known as Bence Jones proteins). The plasma cells proliferate within the bone marrow and lead to extensive bone destruction with osteolytic lesions, osteopenia, and/or pathologic fractures. The normal coupling mechanism of osteoclasts and osteoblasts is lost in MM. Increased osteoclastic activity resulting in bone resorption and suppressed osteoblastic activity, which leads to the lytic lesions and hypercalcemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Small cell lung cancer:
Incorrect: Although this patient is a heavy smoker, which increases the risk for developing small cell lung cancer (SCLC), he has no symptoms specific to the condition (e.g., cough, bloody sputum). Additionally, the x-ray shows lytic lesions whereas SCLC metastases to the spine typically cause osteoblastic lesions. 
❌ Prostate:
Incorrect: Prostate cancer often metastasizes to the bone. It can also cause anemia and elevation of creatinine due to bladder outlet obstruction. However, it is associated with osteoblastic lesions rather than osteolytic lesions. Also, hypercalcemia is rare with prostate cancer.   
❌ Langerhans cell histiocytosis:
Incorrect: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is characterized by clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells and infiltration into tissues throughout the body. Osteolytic bone lesions are present in the majority of patients and are often described as “punched out” lesions. Other signs and symptoms include eczematous rash, oral lesions, and infiltration to the lymph nodes, liver, spleen, and lungs. Langerhans cell histiocytosis would not explain the patient's elevated creatinine and hypercalcemia. 
❌ Gastrointestinal cancer:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal cancer such as colon cancer can explain the patient's anemia and fatigue. However, it rarely causes hypercalcemia and would not explain the elevated creatinine. In addition, gastrointestinal cancer is associated with mixed osteoblastic-osteolytic bone lesions. 
✅ Plasma cell cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up for chronic knee pain. Over the past 6 months, she has been suffering from knee pain that has been progressively worsening. The patient discloses a dull pain, 3/10 around the right knee, and she did not notice any aggravating or alleviating factors. The pain sometimes awakens her from sleep. The patient has tried over the counter pain medication and multiple sessions of physiotherapy with minimal relief. Family history is negative for malignancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is mild swelling around the right knee, and range of motion is limited due to pain. The left knee appears normal. An x-ray of the right knee is obtained and shown below:  


 Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive knee pain and night pain that is unresponsive to medications. The radiograph results show a lytic “soap bubble” like lesion in the distal femur, which is consistent with the diagnosis of a giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma.   

Giant cell tumor of bone is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor often seen in young adults between ages of 20-40. It typically presents as a lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones. Clinically, the tumor may produce arthritis-like pain due to its proximity to the joints and occasionally cause pathologic fracture. On radiography, the tumor forms an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” like lesion. Grossly, it appears as red-brown masses with areas of cystic degeneration. Microscopically, it consists of sheets of osteoclast-type giant cells. Those neoplastic cells express excessive levels of RANKL, which lead to the differentiation of normal osteoclast precursors into osteoclasts. Treatment usually involves curettage, but the tumor has high rates of recurrence.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic).  
❌ Ewing Sarcoma:
Incorrect: Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. The majority of Ewing sarcomas contain a balanced t(11;22) translocation. It commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. The tumor usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with a significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. On histology, small sheets of malignant cells are seen. This patient’s age and tumor location favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Osteoclastoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoid osteoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid osteoma is a benign, bone-producing tumor often seen in adolescents. It typically arises in the cortex of the femur or tibia and has a characteristic lucent nidus of less than 2 cm with surrounding osteosclerotic reaction. Although benign, they present with severe nocturnal pain that is relieved by aspirin and other NSAIDs. This patient has had minimal relief with over-the-counter pain medication.  
❌ Fibrous dysplasia:
Incorrect: Fibrous dysplasia is a benign lesion in which bone is replaced by fibrous connective tissue and abnormal trabecular bone. It usually occurs in young adolescents more commonly in the proximal femur, tibia, ribs, and skull. Most patients are asymptomatic but some may present with pain, swelling, pathologic fractures, or bone deformity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic due to right shoulder pain for the past 2 months. He works as a carpenter and initially thought it was work-related. However, it has recently become more severe and often awakens him at night. The patient describes the pain as dull, deep, and 4/10 in intensity. Medical history is remarkable for diabetes mellitus type 2 manages with metformin. The patient smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years, but quit 5 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, he has difficulty with shoulder movement due to pain. Passive range of motion is full but produces the pain as well. X-ray of shoulder shows a mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesion with a ring-and-arc pattern of calcifications. The cortex appears thickened, but a periosteal reaction is scant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive shoulder pain and night pain. The x-ray shows a mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesion with a ring-and-arc pattern of calcification, favoring the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma. Histopathological examination is required for definitive diagnosis.  

Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-producing tumor. It usually affects individuals in their 40s or older and more commonly affects men. It usually arises in the axial skeleton, such as the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. On imaging, chondrosarcoma presents with mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesions, with a punctate or ring-and-arc pattern of calcifications due to mineralization of the chondroid matrix. Other radiological findings include flocculent densities that destroy the bone cortex and formation of a soft tissue mass. Moreover, while the cortex may be thickened, periosteal reaction is scant or absent.  

It can arise as a primary lesion or secondary to preexisting enchondroma or osteochondroma. Macroscopically, chondrosarcomas are large and bulky, and consist of translucent cartilage with gelatinous areas. Histologically, it produces an abundant cartilage matrix and irregularly shaped lobules of cartilage that permeate the bony trabeculae. Cellularity, cytologic atypia, and mitotic activity vary depending on the grading. Treatment usually involves wide surgical excision with or without chemotherapy.    

Option Analysis

❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma follows a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Paget disease of the bone:
Incorrect: Paget disease of bone is a disorder that interferes with normal bone metabolism and leads to accelerated bone remodeling. Bone lesions may be single or multiple and can be lytic, mixed or blastic depending on the stage. Paget disease is mostly asymptomatic, but some patients may present with bone pain or pain due to deformity or compression. Diagnosis is often incidental following a routine chemistry screen showing elevated ALP and normal serum calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Giant cell tumor:
Incorrect: Giant cell tumor of bone is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor often seen in young adults between the ages of 20-40. It typically presents as a lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones. Clinically, the tumor may produce arthritis-like pain due to its proximity to the joints and occasionally pathologic fracture. On radiography, the tumor forms an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” like lesion. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Chondrosarcoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Plasmacytoma of bone:
Incorrect: Plasmacytoma of bone is classified as a plasma cell neoplasm, a group of entities that typically produce monoclonal antibodies. When presenting with a solitary lesion, it is named solitary plasmacytoma. When presenting with multiple lesions, it is termed multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma and plasmacytoma instead produce lytic “punched out” lesions. Also, the absence of anemia and renal involvement makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive back pain for the past 2 months. The pain is dull, 3/10, and often wakes him at night. The patient denies any trauma, weight loss, or history of radiation. The patient has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years and drinks 2 beers every night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase, calcium level is 7 mg/dL, PTHrP is not detected, and hemoglobin is 8 g/dL. Imaging of the spine shows sclerotic lesions at the L3-4 vertebrae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive back pain, anemia, elevated ALP and low calcium levels. In light of the sclerotic lesions seen on x-ray, the most likely diagnosis is vertebral metastases due to prostate cancer. While metastases to the bone usually cause hypercalcemia, prostate cancer is more commonly associated with hypocalcemia, since it causes osteoblastic lesions. Patients with prostate cancer are often asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. Signs of metastatic disease may include weight loss, weakness or pain due to spinal cord compression, pathologic fractures, fatigue, anemia, hematuria, and signs of chronic renal failure due to bladder outlet obstruction. On imaging, the metastatic lesions are sclerotic (osteoblastic), as seen in this patient.  

The bones are the third most common organ affected by metastases, following the lung and liver. It is also a common location of distant relapse for solid tumors, especially lung, breast, and prostate cancer. The most common locations for metastatic disease are the proximal femurs, vertebral column, sacrum, and pelvis.    



Option Analysis

❌ Multiple myeloma:
Incorrect: Multiple myeloma is a malignant proliferation of plasma cells that produce monoclonal immunoglobulins. The condition is characterized by renal failure, bone pain, hypercalcemia, normocytic anemia, and lytic bone lesions. This patient has osteoblastic bone lesions.   
✅ Prostatic cancer metastasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paget disease of the bone:
Incorrect: Paget disease of bone is a disorder that interferes with normal bone metabolism and leads to accelerated bone remodeling. Bone lesions may be single or multiple and can be lytic, mixed, or blastic depending on the stage. Laboratory findings in Paget disease include normal serum calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels, while ALP is elevated. Also, Paget disease would not explain the patient’s anemia.   
❌ Osteosarcoma :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone tumor. It follows a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. In adults, risk factors of developing osteosarcoma include prior irradiation or chemotherapy, Paget disease, and fibrous dysplasia.   
❌ Osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by loss of trabecular (spongy) and cortical bone mass despite normal bone mineralization. Osteoporosis is usually asymptomatic but may present with fractures after minimal trauma. Laboratory tests will show normal calcium, phosphate, and ALP levels, unlike this patient. On radiography, osteoporosis leads to loss of cortical bone and trabecular bone, rather than sclerotic lesions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to buttock pain, low-grade fever, and fatigue. His parents report that the pain began a few months ago after a fall during a soccer game, but they did not seek care as they thought it would spontaneously resolve. Since then, the pain has increased and often awakens the patient at night. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 110/63 mmHg. On physical examination, there is swelling around the right iliac crest with some pain upon palpation. The neurological exam reveals a mild limp when the child is asked to walk but is otherwise normal. An x-ray reveals an osteolytic lesion surrounded by multiple layers of new bone. Biopsy of the lesion shows round small blue cells. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further analysis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This young boy is presenting with progressive bone pain, low-grade fever, and fatigue. The x-ray shows a characteristic “onion skin” lesion. Finally, the biopsy reveals sheets of small blue cells, confirming the diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma.   

Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. It commonly affects children 5 to 15 years of age. The tumor usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones and the bones of the pelvis. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it manifests as a large lytic lesion with significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. Laboratory tests often show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).  

The majority (85%) of Ewing sarcomas are found positive for a balanced (11;22) translocation that generates an in-frame fusion of the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 to the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. How this fusion leads to the development of Ewing sarcomas remains unclear. Similarly, the origin of the cells has not yet been determined, but is presumed to be mesenchymal stem cells or primitive neuroectodermal cells.  

Option Analysis

❌ TP53 mutation:
Incorrect: TP53, also known as the guardian of the genome, is a tumor suppressor gene and is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer. The product of this gene, the p53 protein, is a transcription factor that prevents neoplastic transformation via temporary cell cycle arrest (quiescence), permanent cell cycle arrest (senescence), or apoptosis. TP53 mutation is associated with certain cases of osteosarcoma as part of Li-Fraumeni-syndrome. However, it is not associated with Ewing sarcoma.  
❌ RB1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: The RB gene, also known as the governor of the cell cycle, is a tumor suppressor gene and a key negative regulator of the cell cycle. The RB gene is located on chromosomal locus 13q14. The product of the RB gene is the RB protein, which regulates the G1/S checkpoint of the cell cycle before DNA replication commences. RB gene germline (inherited) or somatic (acquired) mutations are associated with retinoblastoma eye cancer, osteosarcoma bone cancer, and other soft tissue tumors, but not Ewing sarcoma.   
✅ Fusion of EWS-FLI1 genes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fusion of BCR-ABL genes:
Incorrect: Fusion of BCR-ABL genes is caused by a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (Philadelphia chromosome) and is the pathogenesis of chronic myelogenous leukemia, not Ewing sarcoma.   
❌ VHL gene mutation:
Incorrect: A mutation in this gene leads to von Hippel-Lindau disease. The condition is characterized by the development of multiple tumors, including central nervous system hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic tumors. However, mutations in the VHL gene are not associated with Ewing sarcoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female comes to the office for a follow-up appointment. Two weeks ago, the patient fell during a college basketball game on an overstretched arm. Since then, she has experienced tenderness around the snuffbox of the right hand. An x-ray obtained following the injury failed to demonstrate a scaphoid fracture. However, imaging did show a circular lucent lesion with central irregular calcifications at the metaphysis of the base of the 5th proximal phalanx. The cortex appears intact. Vital signs are within normal limits. Family history and medical history are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has chondroma, a benign tumor of hyaline cartilage that typically develops in the medullary cavity (enchondroma) or on the cortical surface (juxtacortical chondroma). It occurs typically in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. It appears as a metaphyseal lesion of the tubular bones in the hands and feet. While it is usually a solitary lesion, multiple enchondromas are associated with Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome.  

Most enchondromas are asymptomatic and are detected incidentally, as in the case of this patient. Occasionally, they may cause pain or pathologic fracture. On imaging, chondromas are characterized by a well circumscribed lucent lesion with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim, and an intact cortex. Macroscopically, they are usually < 3 cm, gray-blue in color, and translucent. Histologically, they are composed of benign cartilage with central calcifications and peripheral ossification. Solitary lesions rarely undergo sarcomatous transformation, but with enchondromatosis syndromes, the risk is higher. Treatment may include observation or curettage, depending on the clinical course.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Osteoid osteoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid osteoma (OO) is a type of bone-producing tumor which commonly occurs at the cortex of the distal femur or proximal tibia. On histology, the tumor is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. On x-ray, OO appears as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim. Patients often present with pain which responds to NSAIDs. While this patient’s lesion has similar radiological features, the absence of pain, the tumor’s location, and the presence of irregular calcifications all favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Osteoid blastoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid blastoma (OB) is a type of bone-producing tumor which commonly occurs at the vertebrae. On histology, the tumor is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. On x-ray, OB can have variable appearance and may manifest as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim. Patients often present with pain which does not respond to NSAIDs (thus distinguishing it from osteoid osteoma). This patient tumor location and the absence of pain favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Chondroma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chondrosarcoma :
Incorrect: Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilage-producing tumors which are subclassified into conventional (hyaline cartilage–producing), dedifferentiated, clear cell, and mesenchymal types. Chondrosarcomas usually arises in the bone of the pelvis or shoulder and rarely involves the distal extremities. On imaging, it appears as a foci with calcifications or flocculent densities that may destroy the cortex. Clinically, it usually presents as a painful and progressively enlarging mass.   
❌ Osteochondroma :
Incorrect: Osteochondroma (exostosis) is a benign overgrowth of cartilage that can be sessile or pedunculated. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones close to the growth plate. The cap consists of benign hyaline cartilage that undergoes endochondral ossification, with new bone-forming at the inner part. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to persistent right wrist pain. The patient has been experiencing pain on the thumb-side of the wrist every time she holds or grips an object. She recently delivered a healthy, full-term baby four weeks ago. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, swelling and tenderness to palpation are noted at the radial aspect of the right wrist. Repetitive tapping over the volar part of the wrist does not reproduce the pain. While the patient is grasping the right thumb with the right four digits, the physician places the wrist in ulnar deviation. This maneuver reproduces the pain. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis
Entrapment and compression of the median nerve
Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths
Occult fracture of the distal radius

questions.solution:
This patient presents in the postpartum period with pain over the radial aspect of the wrist and a positive Finklestein test. These findings are consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis, characterized by myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

De Quervain tenosynovitis reflects a non-inflammatory thickening of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis as they cross the radial styloid process and through the first extensor compartment. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist. The pain is exacerbated when gripping objects or performing repetitive movements involving the thumb. Risk factors include female sex, being in the postpartum period, and prolonged abduction and extension of the thumb.

The most useful diagnostic aid in evaluating DeQuervain tenosynovitis is the Finklestein test. The thumb is flexed and held inside a fist to perform this test. Afterward, the wrist is moved in the ulnar direction. A positive test is characterized by pain at the radial styloid process or along the length of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis with ulnar deviation of the wrist.

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves rest, analgesia, and wrist splinting. Advanced or refractory cases are typically treated with glucocorticoids or surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Entrapment and compression of the median nerve  :
Incorrect: Carpal tunnel syndrome typically presents with a positive Tinel test, which involves tapping over the median nerve and evaluating reproducible pain or paresthesia. This patient’s negative Tinel test and positive Finklestein test are more indicative of De Quervain tenosynovitis.  
❌ Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths  :
Incorrect: Ganglion cysts are clinically characterized by their round appearance and rubbery texture. No such structures are present on this patient’s physical examination.  
❌ Occult fracture of the distal radius:
Incorrect: A fracture of the distal radius is unlikely without associated trauma.  
❌ Calcium hydroxyapatite arthropathy  :
Incorrect: As the name implies, hydroxyapatite crystal deposition disease (HADD) is characterized by periarticular and intraarticular deposition of hydroxyapatite cysts. While HADD is on the differential for atraumatic swelling and pain of the wrist, this patient has a positive Finklestein test, making DeQuervain tenosynovitis a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for the evaluation of an abnormal protrusion in her abdomen. She is 6 weeks postpartum and reports that there has been a protrusion since she delivered the baby. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and ended with a normal vaginal delivery of a 7-lb. infant. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a slight bulge in the epigastric region. The patient is asked to raise her head while being in the supine position with knees flexed. A diffuse fusiform bulge becomes prominent extending from the xiphoid to the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This postpartum patient presents with a midline abdominal bulge that becomes prominent on the contraction of the rectus abdominis muscle. She most likely has rectus abdominis diastasis, which refers to an abnormal separation between the two medial sides of the rectus muscles, with a laxity at the linea alba. A distance of two centimeters is usually considered abnormal in the midline abdomen above the umbilicus.



Risk factors include elevated intra-abdominal pressure, including obesity and pregnancy; conditions that weaken the abdominal wall (e.g. connective tissue disorders); and prior abdominal surgery. It most commonly affects infants (due to the partially developed rectus abdominis) and pregnant people (especially multiparous, due to repetitive stretching of the abdominal muscles). Of note, rectus abdominis diastasis is not a true hernia, as the midline fascial layer of the abdominal wall is intact; therefore, incarceration and strangulation do not occur.

Affected patients usually present with a midline abdominal ridge that becomes more prominent with straining and may disappear when the abdominal muscles are relaxed. Diagnosis is based on physical examination, and abdominal ultrasound can be performed to rule out hernia.

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric hernia:
Incorrect: Although an epigastric hernia can present as a bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process, it is not usually fusiform, as it is a result of a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall. Moreover, it is less commonly associated with pregnancy than diastasis recti.
✅ Rectus divarication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma results from the disruption of one of the branches of the inferior epigastric artery. This condition presents with acute abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal wall mass that does not change during contraction of the rectus muscle.
❌ Incisional hernia:
Incorrect: An incisional hernia can develop at the site of a previous abdominal incision. Important risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, smoking, malnutrition, and connective tissue disorders. This patient has no surgical history.
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect: A lipoma is a lump under the skin that results from the overgrowth of fat cells. Physical examination usually shows a mobile, painless mass with a soft consistency. This patient, with a new bulge postpartum, is more likely to have diastasis recti.
